Now I will explain the fundamental causes and conditions of Bhanda. Bhanda means 'born by the roadside' in Chinese.
Why is it so?
Bhanda's mother was originally the daughter of a very wealthy elder. The elder had only this one daughter, so he built a seven-story tower to house her and sent a slave to provide for her needs.
As the slave's son grew up, the daughter began to have an affair with him and discussed with the slave:
'I will now elope with you to another country.'
In this way, she asked the slave's son three times, and the slave's son said:
'I cannot go.'
The daughter told the slave:
'If you do not go, my parents will find out and will surely kill you.'
The slave replied:
'If I go to another place, I am poor and have no money or treasures. How can I make a living?'
The daughter said to the slave:
'You follow me, and I will steal precious treasures to take with us.'
The slave replied:
'If it's like that, then I'll go with you.'
This woman stole precious treasures every day and took them out with the slave to hide them outside.

After accumulating two heavy loads, she sent the slave out ahead to make an appointment outside. The woman then put on a maid's clothes, opened the lock on the door, and went out to follow the slave to a distant foreign country, where they settled down.
After one or two years, she became pregnant.
When she was about to give birth, she thought to herself:
'Now that I'm here, if I give birth, there will be no one to take care of me. I miss my mother and want to go home.'
She discussed it with her husband:
'If I give birth, only my mother can take care of me. I want to go back now. Will you go with me?'
The slave husband replied:
'I can't go. Since we ran away, how can we return?'
The family will certainly kill us.'
The wife said to her husband:
'Although women may be angry, they cannot kill their children, so I want to leave.'
Her husband replied:
'If you don't kill me, you will certainly kill me, so I can't go.'
When her husband went into the mountains to cut firewood and was not around, she locked the door and left. When her husband returned and did not see his wife, he asked the neighbors:
'Have you seen my wife?'
They replied:
'Your wife has already left.'
When her husband heard this, he immediately followed her. He caught up with her halfway, and she had already given birth to a son. Her husband said to his wife:
'You left because you wanted to give birth. Now that you have given birth, why do you need to leave?'
When the wife heard this, she was ashamed of her parents, so they returned home together to take care of their livelihood.

Not long after, she became pregnant again. When she was about to give birth, she thought of her mother and ran back home. Halfway there, she gave birth to another son. Her husband chased after her and brought her back halfway.
Because the two children were born on the side of the road, they were named Bhanda.
Bhanda and his brothers were playing with their peers. The two children were very strong and beat their peers. The peers scolded them, saying:
You have no six relatives and are alone here. How dare you hit us?
The children heard this scolding, went home crying, and asked their mother:
Everyone else has six relatives. Why do we alone not have them?ğŸ”½Their mother remained silent and did not answer. The children cried and refused to eat or drink.
Seeing that they were not eating and crying like this, out of love for her two children, the mother told them the truth:

'I am the daughter of a great wealthy elder in such-and-such a country. Your father is a slave in the elder's household. He was sent to serve me, and I became intimate with him and could not part from him. I ran away with him and gave birth to you here.'
After the two heard their mother's words, they said to their mother:
'Please send us back to our parents' home. We cannot live here.'
Their mother did not agree, and the two children cried incessantly. Their mother then discussed with her husband:
'These children cry and refuse to stay here. How can we send them back to their parents' home together?'
Her husband said:
'That's fine.'
They then went together to send them back.
When they arrived, the parents and children all stayed outside the gate. Seeing the family members come out, they said:
'You can go back and tell the elder that the elder's daughter and her husband are now outside the gate.'
When the parents heard this, they replied:
'Let the two children enter. You don't need to see each other.'
The elder immediately sent someone to welcome the two children in. After the children entered, they were bathed with fragrant hot water, anointed with incense, and dressed in necklaces.
The elder took the two children in his lap on his two knees and asked:
How does your mother make a living in another place?
Is she not very poor?
The two children replied:
Our parents are poor in another place, making a living by selling firewood.
When the mother heard this, she felt compassionate and opened the treasury, filled a bag with gold, and sent someone to give it to her daughter, saying:
You keep the two children, I will raise them myself. Take this gold and return to your former residence. Make a good living for yourself, you don't need to see me again.
The two children had grown up and married.
When their parents were old and about to die, they entrusted the family business to the two children. When their parents passed away,

At that time the Buddha was expounding the Dharma to the four assemblies. At that time MahÄbhadra went to where the Buddha was to listen to the Dharma. After hearing the Dharma, he delighted in leaving the household life and returned home to discuss with his younger brother:
'I now wish to leave the household life and entrust the family affairs to you.'
When his younger brother heard his elder brother's words, he was distressed in his heart and said to his elder brother:
'I am now alone and have no one to rely on. If you abandon me and leave the household life, how can I survive?

' His younger brother made this request three times, but his elder brother's mind was firm and unyielding. He entrusted the family affairs to his younger brother and then left the household life. Not long after leaving the household life, he attained arhatship.
After a long time, his younger brother thought to himself:
'My elder brother entrusted the family business to me, which is no different from someone vomiting. How can I accept it and give rise to attachment?
' Because he was disgusted with the world, he went to his elder brother and sought to leave the household life.
The elder brother then had him ordained, taught him a verse, but after four months he could not remember the beginning or end. The elder brother MahÄpanthaka thought to himself:
This person has no affinity with the Buddha's teachings, I should send him back home.
He then said to CÅ«á¸apanthaka:
You are now dull-witted.
He then pulled on his robes and drove him out of the monastery. Outside the gate, he cried and did not want to return home.

At that time, the World-Honored One used his heavenly eye to observe sentient beings. Seeing that CÅ«á¸apanthaka had the causes and conditions for being saved, the World-Honored One went to him and asked CÅ«á¸apanthaka:
Why are you crying here?
He replied to the Buddha, saying:
Since I am dull-witted, I could not memorize a verse after four months. My elder brother MahÄpanthaka drove me out of the monastery because of my dullness.
The Buddha said:
Stop, do not be distressed. I will teach you.
The Dharma teacher said:
Why did you pull out MahÄpanthaka, who has not yet seen the causes and conditions of attaining the Way?
He replied:
Zhoulapanthaka cannot be liberated by the disciples, only the Buddha can liberate him, so I pulled him out.
The World-Honored One comforted his mind and gave Zhoulapanthaka a small piece of white cloth, saying, 'You hold this cloth, face the sun and beat it, and think like this:
'Take away the dirt, take away the dirt.'
After the Buddha instructed him, he entered the village to accept the invitation of VisÄkhÄ's mother. The Buddha observed that Zhoulapanthaka was about to attain the Way, so he spoke a verse, saying:
'One who enters tranquility is joyful, seeing the Dharma and attaining peace and happiness.
In the world, the most blissful is to be free from anger, not harming any sentient being.
In the world, there is no bliss like desire, but transcending desire.
If one can subdue arrogance, this is the supreme bliss.'
CÅ«á¸apanthaka heard these verses from afar and immediately attained the fruit of arhatship.
Question:
Is there a bhiká¹£u who goes to the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« temple to speak the eight precepts and receives three pÄyattikas?
Answer:
There are three pÄyattikas: first, not being appointed by the saá¹ƒgha; second, going to the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« temple; third, staying until sunset.
Going to the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« temple to speak other teachings results in one pÄyattika and two duá¹£ká¹›tas.
What are they?
First, not being appointed by the saá¹ƒgha; second, going to the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« temple - these two are duá¹£ká¹›tas. Staying until sunset is one pÄyattika.
Devadatta, Trimantabhadra, Gandhabhadra, Kukkuá¹­ika, and KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra praise them by revealing their names.
Eating separately from the saá¹ƒgha means there are two kinds of separate meals:
first, invitations; second, begging.
How does one become guilty of eating separately?
If an upÄsaka goes to four bhiká¹£us and invites them with regular food, saying, Venerable sirs, please accept it,
this is called an invitation that becomes eating separately.
If one accepts an invitation at one time, either the next day or some later day, and accepts food at one place, it becomes eating separately, and the four people all commit an offense.
If one accepts an invitation at one time, then goes to the donor's house separately, and accepts food at one time but eats in different places, the offense is the same as before.
The Dharma teacher said:
Why is it so?
Because the food is accepted at one time.
If one accepts an invitation at one time, goes separately, accepts separately, and eats separately, one does not commit an offense.
If one is separately invited and goes separately, and at the donor's house accepts [food] at one time, one commits an offense. This is called committing an offense by accepting an invitation.
How does one commit an offense by begging?
There were four bhiká¹£us who begged for food, either sitting or standing. They saw an upÄsaka and said to him:
'Give us four people some food.'
Or each person begs, saying 'Give me some food', also like this, either going together or each going, receiving food at one time, this is called begging and incurring the offense.
As for the sick, if one's feet are broken and sand and soil enter in, one is unable to walk, so one may receive food from a separate assembly, this is called being sick.
As for the time of making robes, if one obtains cloth and cuts it, or first cuts it to make robes, this is called the time of making robes, up to attaching hooks and clasps to the robe.
As for traveling, down to half a yojana, traveling by boat is also like this.
As for times of famine, up to food not being enough for four people to eat, this is called a time of great famine.
As for alms given by ascetics, whether ascetics of the same Dharma or non-Buddhist ascetics, one may receive food from a separate assembly without offense for seven reasons:

The second is the four-person limit for begging for food, the third is the four-person limit for those who have not yet received full ordination, the fourth is the four-person limit for alms bowls, the fifth is the four-person limit for the sick. These five fours will now be explained in detail.
What is meant by the four-person limit for not accepting invitations?
There are donors who invite four people, but one person knows but does not go to the donor's house. The donor asks:
'Has the senior monk come?'
The three monks reply:
'He has not come.'

The donor is about to eat, and sees a monk, so he invites him in to eat. The four people eat together without committing an offense. This is called the four-person limit for not accepting invitations.
Why do they not commit an offense?
First, because it is not an invitation.
What is meant by the four-person limit for begging for food?
Three people accept the invitation, but one person begs for food and does not accept the invitation, so they do not commit an offense.
The four-person limit for novice monks means inviting three fully ordained monks and one novice monk without committing an offense.
What is meant by the four-person limit for alms bowls?
Inviting three monks and one bowl of food is not an offense.
As for the fourth person being sick, if one invites three monks and one sick monk, it becomes four people and is not an offense.
If one invites four people and there is one monk who understands the Vinaya, if they want to eat together but are afraid of committing an offense, they should make a plan.
When the layperson serves the food, they cover their bowl and do not accept it. The layperson asks:
Why don't you accept it?
They reply:
Just give it to the three people. I want to chant a blessing.
After the three monks have finished eating, they later accept the food and it is not an offense.
If one is invited to be given rice, but at the house they are given meat, it is also an offense. If one is invited to be given rice, but at the house they are given porridge, it is not an offense.
If there is a layperson who wants to feed the monks and sends someone to the temple to invite the monks to accept their food,
among the monks there is a monk who understands the Vinaya who thinks to himself:
There are many monks who practice the dhuta precepts in this sangha. The messenger does not understand the Dharma, so they make this invitation.
The monk who was versed in the Vinaya replied:
We will know tomorrow.
The messenger came again, and still did not understand the request to invite the monks. The monk who knew the Dharma replied:
We will know tomorrow.
In this way, it continued like this until half a month had passed. If they still did not understand, the monk who knew the Dharma said:
If the donor invites the monks in this way, they only get novice monks and not fully ordained monks.
The messenger said:
The Venerable Ones also accept invitations from other families. Why do you not accept my invitation now?
He replied:
It is not that we do not accept the invitation. It is because you still do not understand the Dharma. You should only say you invite the monks, do not say you give them rice gruel, fish, meat, etc.
You should only say you invite the monks. The monks can accept without violating the precepts.
If they instructed in this way, but the messenger still did not understand the words and feared people's criticism, he said:
You should just go.
The Sangha may enter the village to beg for alms the next day, and going to the donor's house to receive food is not an offense.
The detailed explanation of the precept against eating separately from the Sangha is complete.
This is a precept established by the Buddha, and arises from body and mind.

Eating in succession means if a bhiká¹£u has accepted an invitation, but the donor has not yet arrived, the bhiká¹£u fears it will be late and the donor may not come, so he enters the village to beg for alms.
After begging for alms and returning, he sees the invited donor coming. The bhiká¹£u does not eat. The host asks:
Venerable, why don't you eat?
The bhiká¹£u replies:
Because I have accepted the donor's invitation, I cannot eat.
The donor says:
Just eat.
If the donor speaks like this, eating is not an offense.
If many donors invite at the same time, eating like this is not an offense.
The precept against eating in succession is complete.
This is a precept established by the Buddha, and arises from body and mind.

The provisions on the road for a returning bride or traveler, if taking one bowl, one can eat as one wishes or give to others. If taking two bowls, one bowl for oneself and one bowl to give to the bhiká¹£u saá¹ƒgha. If taking three bowls, one bowl for oneself and two bowls to give to the bhiká¹£u saá¹ƒgha. One should not give to lay people one knows, relatives, or donors who invite freely. One should not take more than three bowls.
The Dharma teacher said:
The remaining text is easy to understand.
This is a proscribed offense, arising from body and mind. One is not absolved by ignorance.
The precepts on the provisions on the road for a returning bride are finished.

The five proper foods are rice, millet, sorghum, red rice, and wheat. These five kinds of rice made into porridge, if drawn into characters when first taken out of the cauldron, one should not eat them. If mixed with vegetables to make porridge, it is the same.
If eating with a little rice mixed with much water, one should separate from the proper deportment and perform the ritual for leftover food.
If rice mixed with meat or fish is made into porridge, and the meat is visible like a mustard seed in size, the food should be treated as leftovers.
If the meat is rotten and indistinguishable from the water, the food does not need to be treated as leftovers.
All grass roots and tree seeds used to make rice do not need to be treated as leftovers.
Dried rice refers to dried rice made from millet, white rice, or wheat.
Dried rice is dried in the sun. If dried rice is made from beans or tree seeds, it does not need to be treated as leftovers.
Flour refers to flour made from white rice, millet, or wheat. After eating, the food should be treated as leftovers.
There are two kinds of flour:
one is loose flour, the other is flour mixed with sugar or honey to form a dough.ğŸ”½Because the rice is not crushed, this rice does not need to be treated as leftovers.
If the flour or rice comes out of the food, it does not need to be treated as leftovers.

If one receives food from the five kinds of government officials, if there is food in the bowl or in the hand, and a person is offering food within arm's reach, one should perform the remainder food ritual.

If it is beyond arm's reach, it does not count as a prohibition. If within arm's reach, but one has already swallowed all the food in the mouth, it does not count as a prohibition. If there is still rice in the mouth, and one prohibits within arm's reach, it counts as a prohibition. If it is impure meat that is not suitable to be eaten at all, the prohibition does not count.
Why is it so?
Impure things are not suitable to be eaten.
If one eats impure meat, the prohibition within arm's reach does not count.
If one prohibits and gives to others, it does not count as a prohibition.
Why is it so?
Because one still thinks of not having finished eating.
If one is eating properly, the prohibition and giving to others does not count as a prohibition.
Within arm's reach means within one and a half cubits of one's body. The prohibition counts if within that range, but does not count if beyond that range.
If one brings food and places it on the ground within one arm's reach, but does not offer it to the bhiká¹£u, the prohibition does not count.
If the attendant holds the food in their hand and blocks it, it is considered blocked.
If one gives food to another bhiká¹£u, thinking it is for oneself, if one blocks it, it is not considered blocked.
Blocking is of two kinds:
First, physical blocking; second, verbal blocking.
What is physical blocking?
If one blocks with the hand, shakes the head, or covers the mouth of the bowl with the hand, the blocker says to stop and not to receive.

If vegetables are mixed with fish and meat to make soup, if one says to receive the vegetable soup, the blocking is not considered blocking. If one says to receive the meat soup, the blocking is considered blocking.

If the porridge is made with correct and incorrect ingredients, if the correct name is mentioned, the blocking is considered blocking. If the incorrect name is mentioned, the blocking is not considered blocking.
As for practicing deportment, only boats, carriages, and vehicles are not considered violations.
The leftovers of a sick person means either leftovers from a meal or food that has not yet been eaten, both are considered leftovers.
The precept on leftovers is explained in detail.
This is a precept that arises from body and speech.
All trees, plants, and grasses are not suitable for food. The roots, stems, flowers, and fruits can be taken for the rest of one's life.
There are trees whose entire body can be eaten at any time, there are trees whose fruit can be eaten at any time, the rest are to be taken as medicine for the rest of one's life.
There are trees whose entire body is to be taken as medicine for the rest of one's life.
The extensive explanation of the precept against eating at improper times is finished.

If one begs for fine food, milk, cheese, fish, and meat, one commits a pÄyattika offense. Begging for other food is a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense. Excluding begging for the sake of the sick, it is not an offense.
The precept against begging for fine food is finished.
Excluding water and toothbrushes means that if food is offered by gods, humans, ghosts, animals, or flying birds, it all becomes accepted.
If food is worn on the head or carried on the shoulder and offered to a bhiká¹£u, instructing the bhiká¹£u to take it himself, it does not become accepted.
If it flows down into the bhiká¹£u's hand, it becomes accepted.
If a load is carried up to twenty cubits long with food on both ends, a pure person joins the load and offers it to a bhiká¹£u, accepting one end, the other end also becomes accepted.
If a bhiká¹£u goes for alms and encounters wind, rain, or dust falling into the alms bowl, the bhiká¹£u should think:
'I should ask the novice to go for alms.
' After receiving the food and returning, he should tell the novice:
'When I went for alms today, I encountered wind, rain, and dust falling into the bowl, so I could not accept it.
I asked you to go for alms, and now I am giving it to you.'
After the novice receives it, he should tell the bhiká¹£u:
'This is the novice's food, and now I offer it to you, Venerable.'
If it is offered like this, one may eat it without violating the precepts.
If a bhiká¹£u holds the alms bowl in his hand while eating and falls asleep, and someone places food in the bowl, the bhiká¹£u does not know it and does not accept it.
If one is about to receive food and falls asleep, and someone places food in the bowl, it is accepted.
Why is it so?
Because one has the intention to receive the food.
If the dust is large, one may remove it and eat without violating the precepts. If the dust is fine and cannot be removed, one should have someone else judge it.
If two people are eating together, or if food is being served, and other food splatters into the bhiká¹£u's bowl, it is considered received.
If, during a meal, sweat flows from the forehead into the bowl, it should be received again.
If sweat flows from the arms into the hands, it does not need to be received.
If food is shaken and falls onto the bhiká¹£u's hands as it rolls off the ground, it is considered received.
If a pure person on a tree ties fruit with a rope and gives it to a bhiká¹£u, it is not considered received.
If a person extends their arm up to ten yojanas and passes food to a bhiká¹£u, it is considered received.

If a bhiká¹£u is sick and a novice or a pure person carries the bhiká¹£u while walking and sees fruit, the bhiká¹£u asks the pure person for it. The pure person takes the fruit, turns their hand over on their body, and passes it to the bhiká¹£u, it is considered received.

If a bhiká¹£u is suffering from heat and holds a fruit tree branch while walking to block the sun, and later sees fruit on the branch, they should not move. They should tell a novice to pick the fruit and give it to the bhiká¹£u, and it can be received.
If a boat or cart is carrying food and drink, and the bhiká¹£us pole the boat or pull the cart, moving the food and drink, they may eat without offense.

If many bhiká¹£us are traveling together and there is only one young novice, each bhiká¹£u carries his own provisions. When it is time to eat, each divides his own portion. After the novice has received his portion, he tells the bhiká¹£us:
Now I will take the novice's portion and exchange it with the Venerable One's.

After obtaining the exchange, he further exchanges it with the second senior monk. After obtaining the second senior monk's food, he exchanges it with the third senior monk. In this way, he continues to exchange until there are many. Eating in this way is all without offense.
If the novice does not understand the Dharma, the bhiká¹£us themselves carry their own food portions and exchange them with the novice. The first senior monk obtains the exchange.
The second senior monk further exchanges with the novice. The second senior monk obtains the exchange.
The third senior monk further seeks an exchange. In this way, there are many exchanges, and all obtain the exchanged food without offense.
If a bhiká¹£u is traveling with rice and the novice is too young to cook, the bhiká¹£u may cook himself, but he is not allowed to light a fire.
If he instructs the novice to light a fire and the food is cooked, he may divide it and exchange it with the novice's food without committing an offense.
If he cooks himself, if the food boils over, the bhiká¹£u is not allowed to blow on it or stir it with an implement. All of these are offenses of duá¹£ká¹›ta.
If he vomits food and it has not yet left the throat, he may swallow it again without committing an offense.
If it has left the throat but is in the mouth and he swallows it again, he commits a pÄyantika offense.
If he accepts ginger and it later sprouts, the acceptance is not lost.
If it is purified by fire and later sprouts, the sprouted part should be purified again. There is no offense in eating the part that has not sprouted.
If he first accepts salt and the salt turns into water, the acceptance is not lost.
If there is an urgent illness, he may take and consume feces, urine, and ash himself.
If there is no ash, one can break wood to make fire and make ash.
What is illness?
One can get poisoned or be bitten by a snake.
The Dharma teacher said:
The rest of the text is easy to understand.
This is a prohibitive offense, arising from body and speech.
The two rules about sitting in a donor's house have been explained.
As for sitting alone in an exposed place with a woman, if two people sit together on a bed and speak, and they understand each other within arm's reach, one commits a pÄyattika offense.
If the conversation is not understood, and they are within arm's reach, one commits a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense.
As for Åšramaá¹‡amallaputra, he is the Buddha's cousin's son, who attained the path of saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin in one month after the Buddha's enlightenment.
If a donor offers medicine, it should be used as medicine and not as food.
If one asks for ghee after being given oil, one commits a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense.
As for an elephant army, there are four people on the elephant and eight people below, which is called an elephant army.
As for cavalry, one person is on horseback, and two are on foot, this is called cavalry.
As for chariot troops, four people chase a chariot, this is called chariot troops.
As for infantry, four people follow each other, this is called infantry.

If it is cooked with alcohol, cooked food, or medicine, and has the smell and taste of alcohol, one commits a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense. If it has no smell or taste of alcohol, one may eat it.ğŸ”½If one plays in water up to the ankles, one commits a pÄyantika offense.
If one rocks a boat or plays with water, one commits a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense.
As for the blue color, it may be copper blue, indigo blue, or the color of madder.
The color of madder is the color of mud.
One should apply these three colors to purify it, as small as a sesame seed. If one does not apply them to purify it, one commits a pÄyantika offense.
If a bhiká¹£u knowingly drinks water containing insects, he commits a pÄyantika offense for each swallow.
If one knowingly pours hot water or boiling water on water containing insects, it is the same.
The precept on insects in water is finished.

If a bhiká¹£u knows that another bhiká¹£u has concealed a grave offense, and the second bhiká¹£u also conceals it, and thus hundreds of thousands of people all conceal it together, they all commit a pÄyattika offense.
This is a naturally offensive act, arising from body and mind.
The precept on concealing the offenses of others is finished.

If one is less than twenty years old and wishes to receive the full ordination, one should count the months in the womb and the intercalary months, and if one has reached twenty years old on the fourteenth day of the poá¹£adha, one may receive the precepts.
Traveling together with a group of thieves by agreement is a proscribed offense.
Traveling together with a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« by agreement is a proscribed offense.
It has already been explained in the Vinaya.
As for the heretic Arittha, who has wrong views and touches smoothness, he does not block the heavenly path, nor does he block the path of liberation.

The reason why Arittha gives rise to this wrong view is because he says that even though a stream-enterer or once-returner has a wife and children, it does not obstruct the path. He draws this as a comparison to himself, saying that touching smoothness cannot obstruct the path.
If it is said that smoothness can obstruct the path, then all blankets and hidden bags are also smooth. Why is it said that only the smoothness of a woman can obstruct the path?
The extensive explanation of Ariá¹£á¹­a's wrong views is finished.
Those who study the Vinaya have five virtues, six virtues, seven virtues, eight virtues, nine virtues, ten virtues, and eleven virtues.
What are the five virtues?

First, one protects one's own precepts; second, one can resolve others' doubts; third, one enters the assembly without fear; fourth, one can subdue one's enemies; fifth, one causes the true Dharma to endure.
What is meant by protecting one's own precepts?
Upholding the precepts purely without any lapses is called protecting the precepts.

The Vinaya master does not commit offenses due to six factors: first, not being aimless; second, not being ignorant; third, not being doubtful; fourth, not declaring what is impure to be pure; fifth, not declaring what is pure to be impure; sixth, not being confused.
What is meant by having no direction?
Knowing and doing it on purpose is called having no direction.
As stated in the Vinaya scriptures, knowing and doing it on purpose is an offense. Knowing and concealing it, going to places one should not go, this is called having no direction.
What is meant by ignorance?
This person does not know the characteristics of the precepts, wanting to do and doing it, this is called ignorance and incurring an offense.
What is meant by incurring an offense due to doubt?
Wanting to do it, a doubtful mind arises and one does it, this is called incurring an offense due to doubt.

Now, the rules for losing and not losing the precepts of dependence are explained.

If a disciple and his teacher are traveling together and see their preceptor from a distance, they lose the precepts of dependence. If they see their preceptor but do not think of him as their preceptor, they do not lose the precepts of dependence.
